newsitem.title: UK: Food, cost concerns prompt M&S downgrades.
newsitem.headline: Food, cost concerns prompt M&S downgrades.

text.p: Retail analysts cut forecasts for stores group Marks and Spencer Plc on Tuesday to reflect concerns on costs, a weaker than expected performance for its food business and the impact of the strong pound.
John Richards at NatWest Markets said he was in the process of revising his forecast nearer to the 1.2 billion stg mark from 1.25 billion for 1997/98.
He said food price deflation, investment in staff and the 20 million pounds impact of sterling were behind the adjustment.
"Basically it's confirmation of what people have been worrying about - food deflation...costs are continuing to rise," he said.

Other retail analysts said the group's performance in food looked weaker than people had hoped for. Tony Shiret, retail analyst at Barclays de Zoete Wedd said he would bring his forecast down to 1.19 billion stg from 1.2 billion.
Food sales rose 5.5 percent last year to 2.7 billion stg.
Marks' shares were 15.5 pence lower at 493.5 by 1320 GMT, reflecting the reduction in profit forecasts.
